material.mattext: Which method displays a simple message to the user but does not take any response?
The alert() method
The open() method
The prompt() method
The confirm() method
Which of the following statements uses correct syntax for the alert() method?
alert("This is a message for the user");
document.alert("This is a message for the user");
alert(This is a message for the user);
document.alert(This is a message for the user)
When are semicolons generally used in JavaScript?
To separate statements when there is more than one statement present
At the end of every statement
Never, because they are not required in JavaScript
At the end of every line that does not include a method call
Which JavaScript operator indicates concatenation?

Consider the following code:

alert("Hello " + prompt("what is your name?", "");

Assuming the user's name is Jon, what would the resulting dialog box display when he runs this script and enters his input?
The dialog will display: Hello Jon
The dialog will display: Hello what is your name?
The dialog will display: Hello what is your name? Jon
The dialog will display: Hello

Consider the following JavaScript code:

alert(confirm("Continue?"));

What is the result of this code when run in the browser?
A dialog box displaying Continue? with two buttons labeled Yes and No, followed by a dialog box displaying either True or False depending on user input
A dialog box displaying Continue? with two buttons labeled Yes and No, followed by a dialog displaying either Yes or No depending on user input
Depending on user input, either a dialog box displaying Continue? Confirmed or a dialog box displaying Continue? Canceled
A dialog box displaying Continue? with two buttons labeled Yes and No
Which method is used to ask the user a true-or-false type of question?
The confirm() method
The alert() method
The open() method
The prompt() method
Which of the following JavaScript code segments correctly concatenates the variables x and y into a document.write() statement?
var x = 10, y = 20; document.write("x is " + x + " and y is " + y + ".");
var x = 10, y = 20; document.write("x is " & x & " and y is " & y & ".");
var x = 10, y = 20; document.write(x is & " x " & and y is & " y " & .);
var x = 10, y = 20; document.write(x is + " x " + and y is + " y " + .);
Which of the following uses correct syntax to display text as part of a Web page?
document.write("Text to display");
write("Text to display");
window.write("Text to display");
"Text to display".write();
In JavaScript, what is a data type?
A definition of the type of information a variable holds
A container that holds a value
A word used to achieve specific results
A character used in an expression to store or return a value
Which of the following is a variable data type supported by JavaScript?
String
Integer
No value
Alphanumeric

Consider the following code:

var myVar;
myVar = confirm("continue?");

What is the data type of the value of myVar after execution?
Boolean
Bit
It depends on the user's input
Undefined

Consider the following code:

var myVar1 = "25";
var myVar2 = 25;

What is the difference between myVar1 and myVar2?
The data type
Nothing, they are the same
The value
The scope

Consider the following code:

var yearOfBirth = 1978;
alert("YearOfBirth");

What would the resulting dialog box display?
The dialog will display: YearOfBirth
The dialog will display: 1978
The dialog will display: undefined
The dialog will display: yearOfBirth
Which of the following examples is a valid variable name in JavaScript?
_lastName
first&LastName
1stName
phone#
In JavaScript, what is an argument?
A value passed into a function from outside the function
Any method that returns a value
A named block of code that can be called
A statement that transfers program execution to a subroutine
Which of the following best describes a function?
A named, organized block of code
A feature of JavaScript
Any of the four ways JavaScript can be utilized in a document
A method that takes at least one argument and returns one or more values
Which code snippet demonstrates the correct syntax for a user-defined JavaScript function?
function my_function() { alert("test function"); }
function my function() alert("test function"); }
function my_function() [ alert("test function"); alert(username); ]
function my_function [] { alert("test function"); }
Which of the following is true about calling statements in JavaScript?
Calling statements require parentheses, even if the function does not require arguments to be passed.
It is not necessary to know a function name to create a calling statement.
Calling statements cannot be used for user-defined functions.
Calling statements only work in Internet Explorer and should be avoided.
Why should you use indentation in your JavaScript code?
To make the code easier to read
To make the code platform-independent
To make the code ISO952-compliant
To improve program performance

Consider the following code:

<script type="text/JavaScript">
<!--
var age;
function showAge() {
   getAge();
   alert(age);
}
function getAge() {
   age = prompt("Please enter your age:","18");
}
// -->
</script>
<body onload="showAge();">


In what order will the functions excecute?
First getAge, then showAge
First showAge, then getAge
It depends on whether the system has a multi-thread processor
Only showAge will excecute

Consider the following code:

function counter(x) {
     x++
}
var myVar = 0;
counter(myVar);


What is the value of myVar after execution?
The value is: 0
The value is: 1
The value is: x
The value is: null

Consider the following JavaScript function:

function myFunction(x) {
//your code here
}


Which code statement should be added to the function to return to the calling statement the value of x multiplied by 2?
return x * 2
myFunction = x * 2
x = x * 2

Consider the following JavaScript code:

function concatenate(txt1, txt2) {
   txt1 += " ";
   var myText;
   return txt1 + txt2;
}
var myText = concatenate("Hello","World");


What is the value of myText after execution?
The value is: Hello World
The value is: false
The value is: HelloWorld
The value is: true

Consider the following JavaScript code:

function helloWorld(){
   var myVar = "Hello World";
}
alert(myVar);


What will be the result of this code?
A dialog box that displays: undefined
A dialog box that displays: Hello World
A dialog box that displays: null
A dialog box that displays: helloWorld

Consider the following JavaScript code:

function helloWorld(){
   myVar = "Hello World";
}
helloWorld();
alert(myVar);


What will be the result of this code?
A dialog box that displays: Hello World
A dialog box that displays: null
A dialog box that displays: helloWorld
A dialog box that displays: undefined
How does a global variable differ from local variable?
You can access a global variable value from any function or <script> block you define on the X/HTML page.
You declare a local variable outside of any function.
You declare a global variable within a function.
You can access a local variable value from any function or <script> block you define on the X/HTML page.
Which event occurs when a Web page is launched in the browser?
load
unload
onload
focus
Which of the following is an example of a user-defined JavaScript function?
addSpace()
parseInt()
isNaN()
parseFloat()

Consider the following JavaScript expression:

parseInt("1.5y");


What is the result of this expression?
The result is: 1
The result is: 1.5
The result is: 1.5y
The result is: 4
In JavaScript, what is casting?
A way of changing a variable from one data type to another
A way of repairing corrupted user input
The practice of creating functions molded to pre-defined algorithms
The practice of declaring all variables and creating all objects before programming procedures

Consider the following JavaScript code:

var subTotal = 1;
var tax = 0.03;
alert("The total is " + subTotal * (1 + tax));


What is the result of this code?
A dialog box that displays: The total is 1.03
A dialog box that displays: The total is 10 * 1.03
A dialog box that displays: The total is 1010.03
A dialog box that displays: The total is castError!
